This happens at random but only on the Netflix app. Sent tv back for replacement.2nd tv: received second replacement tv and installed it. Immediately notice another pixel out in the top right of screen.  Back to amazon!3rd Tv: Received and installed immediately noticed a whole cluster of pixels out in middle of screen (5-6) out. And Netflix app still drops sound. Finally called amazon to see if other customers were receiving similar TVs with issues like mine. Amazon customer service very good and upgraded our tv model to the un40f6300 for free.4th Tv: Received (over night) as with the third tv. Installed turned on the new upgraded model and yes a pixel was out in the top right corner. Also the Netflix app still drops sound all the time.In the end, we decided to keep the 4 th tv and live with the out pixel. I believe may TVs coming out today have this issue, but many don't notice. When I visited best buy to see other comp models, I again notice out pixels on many of the brand new TVs. I just think quality control is no existent and nobody really complains or notices. Both Samsung and Netflix blame each other for the sound issue. But it is a Samsung problem, Netflix works on ten other devices in my house just fine.So if you do receive a brand new tv with an out pixel, please return it, it's very easy to do so with amazon. I figure with the shipping back and forth of 7 TVs, amazon is out over $1k in shipping. Maybe they will address this issue with Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Pretty picture, but not so smart tv.
Reviews.Author: J. Crowley "mmcjprof"
Reviews.Content: I got this on sale at a local big box store on a special sale.  I have had Samsung electronics in the past.  This looked great--50 inch wifi, smart tv.  What's not to like?I have called support once and chatted with them three times in two days.  The manual is useless. Out of the box, the TV needs to have a software upgrade.  (Over a high speed connection, the download took 20 minutes.) Software upgrades are not unusual, but the setup does not direct you to set up your network connection and then upgrade the software.  The good news?  Once upgraded, I could connect to Netflix.  The bad news?  I can't seem to connect to other services.  Also, it drops the signal a lot.There are no explanations of the connectors on the back of the TV.  I am hearing impaired, so I use wireless headphones. They worked fine with my old Samsung.  This model does not have RCA connectors (even though their website shows a picture of RCA connectors).  It has only a 3.5mm connector.  The only solution was to buy another connector cable. If you go to the online manual and search for headphones, you get no hits, by the way.The box says wifi in big letters on the front.  However, it's rudimentary.  The TV has no bluetooth capability.  Worse, it does not work with a wireless keyboard.  Why anyone would want to have a wired keyboard connected to a 50 inch TV? If you sit close enough for the keyboard cable to reach, you are too close to the screen.  Every cheap PC can use wireless keyboard.  Sadly, only Samsung TV's from model numbers 6400 and higher can work with a wireless keyboard.  If you can't use a keyboard, entering information (movie or tv titles, etc) has to be done with the arrow keys on the on screen keyboard.  It's at best cumbersome.In the first two of my three online support chats, I mentioned wanting to use a wireless keyboard, and both times they indicated that it was possible.  After the second chat, I bought a new one first checking that it was HID capable. It was only on the third chat that the consultant revealed that the TV did not have the required capability.  I could use a WIRED HID keyboard.So far I have not been able to get the universal remote to work with my set top satellite box, or with my Samsung Blue Ray DVD player.  In fact, to turn on the TV I now have to use both the Samsung remote and the satellite remote. This TV has a list price of $1300.  I do not see any reason that such an expensive piece of electronics would be so firmly mired in the previous century. I am right on the edge of returning it to the store, sale or no sale.  It will certainly be a long time before I purchase another Samsung product.

What the heck is up with that?  I Googled it and apparently it's a bug in the app, but it still really sucks.

Reviews.Title: Problematic
Reviews.Author: Hannah
Reviews.Content: My main problem with this unit is that it is not user-friendly.  The secondary problem was an obvious defect in the monitor that created a vertical white line down the center that remained despite every diagnostic test possible. Of course defects happen, so that is not factoring into this review--it is, nevertheless, impossible not to bring up. :)However, referencing the user-friendly remark, if your TV provider's box doesn't have HDMI ports, you will have a significantly lower quality in TV and be unable to use your universal remote to change the channel--the STB/"smart" feature is absolutely pointless. If you have an Xbox with a 3-point component cable--this monitor needs 5, and you can only plug one device in at a time--you will have to play your games in black and white. I only use the TV for video games, so it's in my best interest to have a cheaper, low tech monitor if it means I can actually have color--the one upstairs is years older, with more component ports, easier access, better quality and almost idiot-proof. The whole situation with this monitor was an exercise in futility. I wasted hours working on fixing something that required tons of extra purchases and in the end still didn't work. I don't want to ever have to deal with this much nonsense from a simple TV again.

Now it can't be that I have been the unfortunate one finding two defective tv's two times in a row. If anyone who owns one of these tv's and is reading this review wants to chime on this, please do so and give it a try yourself. Here are the only sound settings i have changed for you to test out on your tv. Sound mode - set to MOVIE and auto volume set to NORMAL. Those were the only two settings I adjusted. This is a huge let down because I am one of those people who doesn't have a surround system nor do i care to spend the extra money for one. I should be content with tv speaker but these were a major disappointment. Apart from the sound, the tv itself is nice. The screen itself with the 1080p 60hz really sharp and i like the LED over the previous 720p LCD tv I used to have. That is all. It would have received a much better rating if it wasn't for the ticking sound.

Reviews.Title: I LOVE THIS TV!!  Ignore my original review!
Reviews.Author: Lori L. Davis
Reviews.Content: Update:  December 22, 2013Forget what you read before (no longer a brick).  Not sure who to blame...my Internet Service Provider (ISP) or the requirements of the television.  Maybe a they can share the blame, but I LOVE MY SAMSUNG SMART TV!!!The Original IssueSimply could not connect to the internet - even though every other wireless device connected beautifully).  I was never able to get as far as seeing the app menu or anything great like that.  Just continued to receive the error message indicated in my original reivew.The SolutionSamsung Customer Service(no help)I first tried to speak to the Samsung customer service folks, and I received no help at all.  To be honest, I could tell they were reading from a script.  I spoke to three different reps and they all used the same words and sentences.  Oh well.  I still give Samsung Customer Service zero stars, but it isn't their fault.  You can tell they have no knowledge of troubleshooting other than what is on the screen in front of them.My ISP (problem resolved)I was able to speak to a tech guy with my ISP.  He said that he was aware of this issue with other Samsung Smart TVs (not sure if it is just my ISP's compatibility with said TV or simply a problem inherent to Samsung TVs).  The solution was to change from a Dynamic IP Address to a Static IP Address.  That was it.  Problem solved.  Samsung never even suggested this solution.MY NEW REVIEWI love this TV - it is SO FUN!  I downloaded the screen-mirror app onto all of my ipads (iPad Mini, iPad Air, & iPad 3) and we are loving it!!!  This is probably one of the coolest features.  I now have a mini-television wherever I want it (bathtub, kitchen, garage, deck, etc).  So COOL!!!  And of course - access to Netflix and Amazon (my go-to apps) are awesome!  The remote control has a button to quickly get there without a lot of hupla.  Love that so much!!!  The image itself is simply beautiful.  I really bought this product for the "smart" features, so that is my focus for now.  I haven't really been able to do much with the browser...I think i need a wireless keyboard to really use that to it's fullest extent.Anyway - my apologies for the first review.  I jumped the gun.  LOVE LOVE LOVE!!!Original ReviewMy first message states that I have a connection.  Any attempt to complete the connection and I get an "internet connection not stable" message.I started with wireless, and then I moved to straight wired.  Disconnected my router completely to remove competing devices.  Same message.  Otherwise, my Roku, my three iPads, my iPhone, my x-box, and my 2 laptops connect flawlessly.Any suggestions out there?

Reviews.Content: this is an excellent TV technically.  The blacks are shockingly black and the sunny scenes make your eyes hurt with squinting.  Its the best picture I've ever seen. But it too easily blurs the line between reality and fantasy but providing such a convincing illusion that near complete submersion in non-reality is a strong possibility and even a probability that is harmful to human nature and good judgement.  This TV causes one to be convinced that magical thinking might actually be a reasonable approach to daily living.  The TV seems more real at times than looking out a window.  Not recommended.  There should always be an absolutely clear and identifiable boundary between what is real and what is not.

Reviews.Title: do not buy
Reviews.Author: Joe
Reviews.Content: I own an older version of this TV. When it just got off warranty it started having some issues with image. You can find a lot of complaints if you ggle 'horizontal lines and ghosting samsung'. Apparently the problem is created by samsung, to save some money, making a decision to put cheap chinese parts in their tvs that deteriorate very quickly, within ~1-2 years. This is perfectly timed with their warranty period. So if you do not want to buy a new $1K tv every two years do not buy this product. Id suggest that you read testimonial on forums first.
